Since, however, the dispersion of error is a step, and that not an unimportant one, towards the attainment of truth, a few sentences may be devoted in examining the accuracy of the statements hitherto promulgated as to the authorship, anti- quity, etc. of this Chronicle, before venturing to make any ob- servations upon these important subjecta

Nicolson‚ Dalrymple, and otherS, state that it is partly the production of English writerS, partly of Scotchmen. The first portion, which they ascribe to an English author, extendS, say they, to about the period ‘⁶ when the little convent of Dundrai- nand was founded;”* in confirmation of which they add that Bede is styled ‘⁶ decus et gloria gentis nostrce.”† It might be urged, with great reason, that the writer of that introduction, considering Bede, as he afterwards styles him, ‘⁶ doctor non solum Anglorum verum etiam universae . . . . ecclesiae,’' might, without any breach of national feeling, use the words “ gentis nostrae,·'’ seeing that the great luminary of the Saxon church, whom he so much admireS, and whose labours it was the object

’ of his present employment to continue, was born, spent a long

life, and died, within less than a hundred miles of Melrose. But it may rather be remarked, that to adduce such an expression as proof of the English authorship of this part of the Chroniele, betrays a forgetfulness of the relative position and circumstances of the two countries when these words were penned.
